entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French amounter, from amount upward, from a- (from Latin ad-) + mont mountain mount

def.dt: :to be equivalent acts that amount to treason
:to reach in kind or quality wants her son to amount to something doesn't amount to much
:to reach a total :add up the bill amounts to $10
:the quantity at hand or under consideration has an enormous amount of energy
:a principal sum and the interest on it

entry.pt: Number is regularly used with count nouns a large number of mistakes any number of times while amount is mainly used with mass nouns annual amount of rainfall a substantial amount of money. The use of amount with count nouns has been frequently criticized; it usually occurs when the number of things is thought of as a mass or collection glad to furnish any amount of black pebbles New Yorker a substantial amount of film offers Lily Tomlin or when money is involved a substantial amount of loans E. R. Black.
